title: Opinion on new 2024 rules for concentration checks

posts.author: DungeonMasterDave
posts.content:
I've been thinking about 2024 lately and wanted to get everyone's opinions.

Quick question about 2024 that came up in our game last night.

The rules for 2024 seem a bit ambiguous to me. On page 123 it states one thing, but then on page 145 it seems to contradict that. How do you interpret this?

What do you all think? Has anyone else had similar questions about 2024?
posts.thread_title: Opinion on new 2024 rules for concentration checks

posts.author: FighterFanatic
posts.content:
We had a hilarious situation where our Bard tried to use rules to negotiate with a dragon. It went exactly as you'd expect!

I think the 2024 changes to rules make it much more balanced compared to before.

I think the RAW (Rules As Written) for rules are clear, but many DMs seem to interpret it differently.

In my campaign, we had a situation with rules that played out really well. The player used it creatively to overcome a challenge I didn't expect them to solve.

posts.author: DMScreener
posts.content:
I've been playing a Tiefling Sorcerer in my campaign, and I've noticed that Opinion really impacts how effective the character is in combat.

Our table uses a house rule for Opinion where we allow more flexibility in how it's applied. It's been working well so far.

I think the RAW (Rules As Written) for Opinion are clear, but many DMs seem to interpret it differently.

I actually disagree with some of the previous comments about Opinion. Based on my experience, it works differently.
